Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Cannot connect account with work Microsoft account" (#8394) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi Nuget team!

Can you please assist me with my problem? I'm trying to create an account in Nuget.org and link it with work Microsoft account
Somehow I have created login+password account and now I'm getting this window:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30490978/105715159-4e328480-5f2e-11eb-98bb-aa1a7a80e3d1.png)

I\m understand that is correct behaviour of the site, because login+pass Auth has beem discontinued. When I am trying to log in with Mircosoft after choosing my accnount I'm getting this: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30490978/105715347-8a65e500-5f2e-11eb-914f-811f0ceb242f.png)

I am expected to be logged in Nuget.org site, but got Need admin approval error. First, I tried to find person in company that related to creating Nuget accounts but no one knows about it inside company. 

I hope that you can help with this problem, 
Thanks
Andrey

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add E2E test for vulnerability" (#7654) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
- Create a dummy "Vulnerability" record and "VulnerablePackageVersionRange" that applies to all versions of "E2E.Vulnerable".
- Create an E2E test that checks that the package was marked vulnerable in registration as expected.
- Update other E2E tests to verify that the package being fetched does not have vulnerability metadata.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Visual Studio NuGet Package Manager incorrectly displays v1.0.0 as installed package version on private feed after updating to V16.8" (#10517) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity2.visualstudio.com/t/Visual-Studio-NuGet-Package-Manager-inco/1302707)._ --- After upgrading from Visual Studio 16.7 => 16.8.3 the Visual Studio NuGet package manager window seems to suggest v1.0.0 as the installed and latest version for some packages (even though that version may not even exist). I've noticed this happens on our own private AzureDevOps Package feed. A particular issue arises with packages that start 0.x.y (i.e. sub v1 packages), where it suggests the latest stable version is v1.0.0 where the package doesn't even exist in the feed. For some other packages it thinks the installed version of a package is v1.0.0, when for example it's actually v1.2.0 in the project file and clicking update does nothing. A temporary workaround (if another version exists) is to update to another version and then to the desired version, but it only stops this happening for the session and the problem recurs when you re-load the solution. In short, as shown in repro recording, it seems to have a v1.0.0 fixation somewhere, which has happened after the update to 16.8.3 from 16.7. --- ### Original Comments #### Simon Gregory on 1/6/2021, 07:36 AM:

I would also add that this also means that it never suggests package updates for any 0.x.y packages with newer versions available, as it ‘thinks’ it has the later v1.0.0 version installed.

#### Feedback Bot on 1/6/2021, 10:15 PM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### Heng Liu [MSFT] on 1/14/2021, 04:14 PM:

I saw the in the screenshots that you have both project reference and package reference on the same name.
NuGet doesn’t support for both project reference and package reference on the same name.

I could repro if I have project A and package reference A at the same time.
But if I only have package reference A, there is no problem with updating on versions lower than 1.0.0.

Could you try removing project reference on Limeglass.Conversion.Abstractions and see if it’s good?
If it still happens, please provide more details on the repro steps. Thanks!

#### Simon Gregory on 1/26/2021, 02:54 PM:

Hi Heng Liu,

When I get a chance I will try your suggestion on removing the ProjectReferences and update you with the result, but it certainly makes sense why it affects some and not others.

This worked fine in the previous version, so is a breaking change for the scenario where you need to switch between PackageReference or ProjectReference to the same library (as discussed in depth here: https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/1151 ).

If you are developing applications with dependent projects that later become NuGet packages, but you need to develop with them in their ProjectReference form this appeared to be the only workaround we’ve found to work, but now it’s broken.

Do you know why has this behaviour changed and how can Visual Studio can support working on ProjectReferences in Visual Studio that later build into NuGet packages?

--- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "All packages are up-to-date but Visual Studio still reports a deprecated package" (#10516) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity2.visualstudio.com/t/All-packages-are-up-to-date-but-Visual-S/1296626)._ --- [severity:It bothers me. A fix would be nice] ![dasdas.png](https://aka.ms/dc/image?name=B8acc61af04854b6d8eb5b2106689949d637444978311148745_dasdas.png&tid=8acc61af04854b6d8eb5b2106689949d637444978311148745) Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2019 Preview Version 16.9.0 Preview 2.0 Project: ASP.NET 5 Issue: Visual Studio permanently shows in the NuGet visualization that a package would ism deprecated - but all packages are up-to-date. If the error were true, it would also be good to know which package (we are close to 2021, please show the package instead to a plain number please!). --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 12/27/2020, 06:20 PM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### eryondon [MSFT] on 12/28/2020, 02:06 PM:

Here “deprecated” and “not up to date” are 2 different concept.
You can have the last and most to date version of package installed, but it still can be “deprecated” because owner of package stopped taking care of it some time ago or some other reason like security etc.
Can you share the name of “package” in question?
You can find more info about deprecation from below link.

  • https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/deprecate-packages

Please let me know.

Why do we ask for more info?
We try to reproduce all issues reported with the information provided in the description and comments. When we can’t reproduce the issue, we ask you for more information so we can resolve the issue as quickly and efficiently as possible.
In our guidelines, you can get tips on how to provide clear and simple reproducible steps.

#### Feedback Bot on 1/5/2021, 07:26 PM: We will close this report in 14 days because we don’t have enough information to investigate further. To keep the problem open, please provide the requested details. #### Benjamin Abt on 1/14/2021, 01:34 PM:

Hi roger

i didn’t even see that i received any replies here; didn’t vote for anything either. must have overlooked the mails while on vacation.

it is true that i could not give more info, because i complain that this info is missing.

--- ### Original Solutions #### Roger Stein Grading solved on 1/14/2021, 09:53 AM, 0 votes:

Hey @Benjamin Abt!

Even though apparently you were misunderstood by both @eryondon [MSFT] and @Feedback Bot since you were asked what package was in question (which was kinda what you wondered about, which you suggested would be better feedback in Visual Studio than simply stating how many packages were found deprecated - LOL xD), still an answer to your question is found at the link you got (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/deprecate-packages).


Here's a screenshot from it (answer/solution) :

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PM UI:  cannot bulk update packages" (#10510) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10510 regressed PM UI update scenarios.  The root problem is [this](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/commit/c995174aaea8d55e1504e9afba83696922497712#diff-80991ce1edef4f242608751b70dd2d48dad8e24a28dbefd2b68a3a7784a12f21R1556) change.  Previously, updating selected packages in the Updates tab of PM UI passes the package identities for the _desired_ packages.  This commit passes the package identities for the _currently installed_ packages.  As a result, PM UI now reports that are no actions to perform.

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | Visual Studio | MSBuild.exe | dotnet.exe):  Visual Studio PM UI

### Product version: 
Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2019 Int Preview
Version 16.10.0 Preview 1.0 [30929.219.main]
NuGet:  latest dev (@ commit 4991066d8d78053b389b07819afba78b88e66340)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:   dev 5.9.0.7083

## Repro steps

1.  Create a new C# ASP.NET Web Application (.NET Framework) with these options:

    *  Framework:  .NET Framework 4.8
    *  Type:  Web Forms

2.  In Solution Explorer right-click on the project node and select "Manage NuGet Packages..."
3.  In NuGet Package Manager UI navigate to the Updates tab.
4.  Check (enable) the "Select all packages" checkbox.
5.  Click the Update button.

### Expected result
Error List:  "Unable to resolve dependencies. 'bootstrap 5.0.0-beta1' is not compatible with 'AspNet.ScriptManager.bootstrap 4.5.3 constraint: bootstrap (>= 4.5.2 && < 4.5.4)'.	"		

### Actual result
*  Error List:  "An internal error occurred. Please contact Microsoft Support."	
*  Output window's "Package Manager" pane:

```
Attempting to gather dependency information for multiple packages with respect to project 'WebApplication1', targeting '.NETFramework,Version=v4.8'
Gathering dependency information took 827 ms
Attempting to resolve dependencies for multiple packages.
Resolving dependency information took 0 ms
Resolving actions install multiple packages
Resolution was successful but resulted in no action
There are no new updates available.
No package updates are available from the current package source for project 'WebApplication1'.
StreamJsonRpc.RemoteInvocationException: An internal error occurred. Please contact Microsoft Support.
   at Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework.ServiceJsonRpcDescriptor.LocalProxyGeneration.<ReturnedValueTaskOfTHelper>d__25`1.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at System.Threading.Tasks.ValueTask`1.get_Result()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ValueTaskAwaiter`1.GetResult()
   at NuGet.PackageManagement.UI.UIActionEngine.<ShouldContinueDueToDotnetDeprecationAsync>d__16.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ValueTaskAwaiter`1.GetResult()
   at NuGet.PackageManagement.UI.UIActionEngine.<>c__DisplayClass11_0.<<PerformActionImplAsync>b__0>d.MoveNext()
RPC server exception:
Microsoft.Assumes+InternalErrorException: An internal error occurred. Please contact Microsoft Support.
      at Microsoft.Assumes.Fail(String message)
      at Microsoft.Assumes.True(Boolean condition, String message)
      at Microsoft.Assumes.NotNullOrEmpty[T](ICollection`1 values)
      at NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio.NuGetProjectManagerService.<GetProjectsWithDeprecatedDotnetFrameworkAsync>d__22.MoveNext()
   --- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
      at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
      at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
      at System.Threading.Tasks.ValueTask`1.get_Result()
      at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ConfiguredValueTaskAwaitable`1.ConfiguredValueTaskAwaiter.GetResult()
      at Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework.ServiceJsonRpcDescriptor.LocalProxyGeneration.<ReturnedValueTaskOfTHelper>d__25`1.MoveNext()

Time Elapsed: 00:00:01.0345980
========== Finished ==========
```

### Verbose Logs

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Test Failure] “Browse” tab can’t show the embedded icon of the package from DevOps feed" (#9250) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.6.0.6479
VS Version: Master\29902.138
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-RS5
## Detailed repro steps 
1.	Create a Console App (.NET Core 3.1) in VS and open the PM UI of the solution.
2.	Add the [DevOps feed](https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/farhub/_packaging/farhub/nuget/v3/index.json ) into the Settings->NuGet Package Manager->Package Sources.
3.  Select the new added DevOps feed in the Package source dropdown box in the PM UI and install the package [**classlib.net48 -version 1.0.5** (don’t have the backlash problem in bug 9225), **dotnet.icon -version 1.0.0** (embedded icon)]
4.  Check all the tabs in PM UI. 
## Expected
The embedded icon should show correctly in all the tabs of PM UI.
## Actual
Only “Browse” tab can’t show the embedded icon of the package from DevOps feed as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/75776381-df38c400-5d8e-11ea-93ce-c4cda3a6d87e.png)

## Note
It doesn't repro for the nuget.org feed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet restore failing on .NET 5 for Debian-based OSes" (#49) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hey Everyone,

Our preliminary investigation shows that .NET 5 restore is broken for Debian-based operating systems including Docker thus resulting in error messages like:

```
error NU3037: Package 'System.Memory 4.5.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The author primary signature validity period has expired.
```

### [Debian Versions](https://www.debian.org/releases/)
- We're currently aware that Debian 10 ("buster") and earlier versions are affected. ❌
- We do know that Debian testing ("bullseye") and later are not affected. ✔

This is because of an [issue reported](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=962596) in the `ca-certificates` package in which the root CA being used are not trusted and must be installed manually due to [Symantec Issues](https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA:Symantec_Issues). Because this issue has been resolved recently in version 20210119 of this package, it is not available in a Debian version as provided in `dotnet-docker` for `buster-slim` today.

## Workarounds

- Manually update the [ca-certificates](https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/ca-certificates) package to version 20210119 including a `bullseye` or later version.
- Consider using a different Debian-based Docker image such as `alpine` or `focal`.
 
## Solution

We're currently working to update the `dotnet-docker`'s `buster-slim` image to update the `ca-certificates` package to 20210119 that resolves this issue. We are however currently verifying this is a viable solution with no large diffs between the `buster` and `bullseye` releases.

Additionally, the `ca-certificates` package is due to be installed in the Debian FTP archive which will promote this fix to the `buster` release in the next few days to which an updated `buster-slim` image will be prepared and released when available.

## Stay Updated

- We are continuing to investigate this issue and will let you know more as we find out.
- We'll continue to update the discussion at https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10491.
- We will also continue posting updates on https://status.nuget.org and on Twitter @NuGet.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)
